elements.title: Maurice Mouvet (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Florence Walton and Maurice Mouvet (pictured) became the first American dancers to appear by command of British royalty when they performed at the 1914 Kenwood House ball?

elements.title: Ichabod Chauncey (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the nonconformist minister Ichabod Chauncey was banished from England under the Religion Act 1592 and spent two years in exile in Holland where he published a defence of his actions?

elements.title: Walnut Grove Dam (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that rather than warning those downriver of the impending failure of the Walnut Grove Dam, a messenger got drunk, leading to the deaths of more than 100 people?

elements.title: Disclose.tv (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the fake news website Disclose.tv plagiarized many of its articles when it relaunched in September 2021?

elements.title: Roberts's triangle theorem (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that it took 90 years to replace the "unconvincing" original proof of Roberts's triangle theorem, on the number of triangles formed by systems of lines, with a correct proof?

elements.title: View from Williamsburg, Brooklyn, on Manhattan, 9/11 (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that View from Williamsburg, Brooklyn, on Manhattan, 9/11 taken on the day of the attacks on the World Trade Center was not published until 2005 because it seemed too pretty to its creator Thomas Hoepker?

elements.title: 1742 siege of Tiberias (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Sulayman Pasha al-Azm lifted his 1742 siege of Tiberias to lead the Hajj pilgrim caravan to Mecca?

elements.title: Nick Sciba (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that in two days, Nick Sciba went from selling fish to playing in the National Football League?
